10.1016/j.mcat.2024.113947 Fig. 1 The optimized lattice structure of θ-Fe3C(031) surface in top and side views. Fig 1 Fig. 2 The mechanism of C vacancy formation and the relative energy profile on θ-Fe3C(031) surface. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) Lattice structures of the most stable adsorption of CO2, H, CO, H2O, CH4, C2H4 and C2H6 on the θ-Fe3C(031) surface. (b)-(d) Energy fluctuations during the simulation. The inset shows the CO2* lattice structure in real time during a constant temperature process. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Energy profiles of possible CO2 dissociation pathways on the θ-Fe3C(031). Fig 4 Fig. 5 COHP analysis of (a) the C-O bonding interaction in the configuration for CO2 adsorption and (b) the C-H and O-H bonds interaction in the configuration for HCOO* and COOH* transition states over θ-Fe3C(031). Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) Projected density of state of the Fe 3d, C and O s + p bands for CO2 adsorption, (b) electron density difference maps and (c) electron localization function map of the CO2 dissociation transition states over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface. The unit for electron density is e bohr−3. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Energy profiles of initial CO2 hydrogenation conversions on the θ-Fe3C(031) surface. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Charge density difference in C-H and O-H bonds formation during CO2 hydrogenation over θ-Fe3C(031) surface. Yellow and cyan regions stand for charge accumulation and depletion of the catalyst, respectively. Fig 8 Fig. 9 Energy profiles for CO2* direct dissociation, carbon monoxide hydrogenation to produce HCO* and COH* intermediates. Fig 9 Fig. 10 Energy profiles for CH4 production through CO2 direct dissociation pathway over θ-Fe3C(031). Catalytic conversion of carbon dioxide into high-value compounds is a promising strategy for reducing carbon dioxide emissions. In the reduction of CO2 to hydrocarbons, the active point and reaction mechanism of iron-based catalysts are still unclear. Here, we systematically investigated the complete reaction path of carbon dioxide hydrogenation to methane, ethylene, ethane, and carbon monoxide over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface using first principles calculations. The electronic structure analysis shows that carbon dioxide tends to dissociate directly on the θ-Fe3C(031) surface to form CO* instead of COOH* and HCOO* intermediates. Due to the high energy barrier for CO* hydrogenation, it tends to desorb forming CO product instead of further transformation into hydrocarbons. In addition, the microkinetic model proved that the H* species coverage on the θ-Fe3C(031) crystal surface is highly, which could effectively inhibit the further oxidation of the catalyst, indicating the catalyst to be highly stable. Meanwhile, carbon monoxide behaved the highest relative selectivity. These results reveal the key intermediates and reaction paths of carbon dioxide hydrogenation over θ-Fe3C(031) catalyst surface and further illustrate the key factors affecting its product selectivity, providing a theoretical basis and guidance for the design and synthesis of the catalyst. Graphical abstract The Carbon dioxide hydrogenation on the surface of θ-Fe3C(031) catalyst exhibits excellent stability and high relative selectivity of CO. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbon dioxide hydrogenation Hydrocarbons θ-Fe3C Density functional theory Microkinetic modeling Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. Introduction The high concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere brings many crises and challenges, such as global warming, glacial melting and other environmental problems [1]. In order to reduce the impact of CO2 emissions on the environment and climate, the development of high-efficiency technologies for the production of highly valuable products and fuels from CO2 resources is currently being extensively researched [2–4]. Hydrogenation of CO2 to various products is an exciting area of research, and the process can reduce CO2 emissions and create valuable chemical products, which has attracted research interests [5,6]. The reduction of carbon dioxide through a reverse water gas transfer reaction to carbon monoxide followed by a Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) reaction produces the higher hydrocarbons, which is a way to produce high value-added products through carbon dioxide hydrogenation [7]. Iron-, cobalt- and nickel-based active metals are the best performing catalysts in FTS [8]. Compared with Co and Ru, Fe-based catalysts have received much attention for their higher activity, lower cost and lower CH4 selectivity [9,10]. In the actual reaction of CO2 hydrogenation on the iron-based catalysts [11], the phase of the catalyst will change, including the conversion of Fe, Fe3O4, θ-Fe3C and χ-Fe5C2, etc. [12–15]. This enables consecutive reactions of CO2 hydrogenation to occur on iron-based catalysts. Due to the excessively complex phase state of the iron-based catalyst in the reaction, the intermediate-phase reaction mechanism has remained to be investigated, especially the activation and conversion of CO2 molecules in different phases. It has been shown that carbon dioxide generally tends to form hydrogenation products, such as carbon monoxide as well as methane via CO* and HCOO* intermediates on the Fe(100) crystal plane [16,17]. The iron oxide and iron carbide are in dynamic equilibrium. Fe3O4 is a good catalyst for reverse water–gas shift (RWGS). The main hydrogenation product of carbon dioxide on Fe3O4 is carbon monoxide [18,19]. At present, a large number of experiments and theoretical calculations show that the iron carbides are the activity species of iron-based catalysts in FTS [20,21]. The χ-Fe5C2 and θ-Fe3C are relatively stable active species of iron carbide in the process of reaction [22,23]. Of the two, the χ-Fe5C2 shows a high selectivity of CO2 hydrogenation to CH4 [8], which is unfavorable for carbon-hydrogen coupling to generate multi-carbon products. Nie et al. [13] reported CO2 dissociation energy barriers as low as 0.64 eV for CO2 on the surface of χ-Fe5C2(510), while the dissociation energy barrier for Fe3O4 (111) exceeds 2.0 eV. Tirma Herranz et al. experimentally verified that θ-Fe3C exhibits the highest stability during oxidation [24]. And θ-Fe3C has high FTS performance at high temperature under the synergistic effect of Mn promoter. However, iron carbide has a higher intrinsic activity than magnetite in CO2 activation and hydrogenation. The role of θ-Fe3C catalysts within them and in the formation of high-carbon chain hydrocarbon products from CO2 hydrogenation is still unclear, and understanding the mechanisms of carbon dioxide activation and conversion on θ-Fe3C catalysts is crucial for the development strategies to effectively decrease CO2 emissions and increase renewable resources. Therefore, the mechanism of the carbon dioxide hydrogenation reaction requires to be studied in detail. In this work, the reaction process and reaction mechanism of carbon dioxide hydrogenation over θ-Fe3C catalyst are systematically investigated by first principles calculations. The electronic structure of reaction intermediates during the CO2 hydrogenation reaction over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface is analyzed. It is found that CO2* would dissociate directly and form CO* intermediates. And the CO* intermediates tend to desorb to form CO rather than further conversion to hydrocarbons. In addition, a microkinetic model is established to study the mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation. The results show that the coverage of H* species over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface is higher compared to other species. This effectively inhibits the further oxidation of the catalyst, which indicates a good stability of the catalyst. Moreover, CO has the highest selectivity. These results reveal the critical intermediates and the optimal reaction pathways in the CO2 hydrogenation over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface, providing a theoretical basis and guidance for the catalyst design and synthesis. Computational details All calculations were conducted using the Vienna ab-initio simulation package, which is based on density functional theory [25,26]. The electronic exchange and correlation energies were processed at a generalized gradient approximation (GGA) level using Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof functions (PBE) [27]. The cutoff energy of the plane-wave base group was set to 400 eV to describe the valence electrons states, and the core electrons states were processed by the projector augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotentials [28]. The spin polarization calculation was considered. The convergence threshold of the forces on the atoms in the electronic self-consistency cycle step was set to 10−5 eV. And all the lattice structures and atomic positions were relaxed completely until the remaining forces in the relaxation of the structure were less than 0.01 eV/Å to finish the self-consistent force calculation. The integration method used was Gaussian smearing with 0.05 eV width. The invariable van der Waals force was considered in the system for calculating molecular adsorption. The adsorption energy (E ads) of the surface species is defined as (1) E ads = E total − E slab − E species where E total is the total energy of the adsorbed species with catalyst, E slab and E species represent the energy of the unoccupied slab and species in the gas phase, respectively. Transition states were localized by means of the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) [29] and that for each transition state was identified as having an imaginary vibrational frequency along the coordinates of the response. The detailed transition state calculation is shown in the Supplementary material. Bader charge was analyzed using the code developed by Henkelman and co-workers [30]. The reaction energies of endothermic and exothermic reactions are expressed as positive and negative values, respectively. Wang et al. and Liu et al. investigated the equilibrium morphology of θ-Fe3C catalyst using Wulff construction method [31,32], and the results showed that the θ-Fe3C(031) crystal face catalyst has the lowest surface energy and the largest exposure ratio. Therefore, θ-Fe3C(031) was chosen as the object of study in this work, and its lattice structure is shown in Fig. 1 . The K-point grid used 2 × 2 × 1 to ample the Brillouin zone. A three-layer θ-Fe3C(031) (3 × 3) supercell was constructed to avoid cell-cell interaction, in which the upper layer is completely relaxed in the interaction with small molecules and intermediates, and the lower two layers are fixed in the initial position. To avoid periodic layer-by-layer interaction of the structure in the z-direction, a 15 Å thick vacuum layer was provided. The van der Waals interaction was modified by DFT-D3 method. On the θ-Fe3C(031) surface, the exposed iron-carbon atom ratio is 3:1, which is the same as the bulk phase atom ratio of the catalyst. There are four 3-fold hollow sites and one 4-fold hollow site on the catalyst surface. In actual reaction conditions, the ratio of hydrogen to carbon dioxide is generally 3:1, and the presence of hydrogen may lead to hydrogenation of exposed carbon atoms on the surface. Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulation with NVT canonical ensembles was used to determine the most stable adsorption configuration. The models for AIMD simulations used geometry-optimized by VASP calculations. The Nosé-Hoover heat bath method was chosen. First, the temperature was raised from 10 K to 673.15 K with the time step set to 1 fs and the total simulation duration of annealing set to 5 ps. Then, the time step was set to 1 fs, keeping the 673.15 K simulation duration set to 5 ps to reach a thermostatic equilibrium state. In order to accelerate the AIMD calculations, the K-mesh used gamma-point. Other parameters are consistent with those of the VASP calculation. In order to determine the role of the θ-Fe3C surface carbon on the hydrogenation reaction, the hydrogenation process with surface carbon was first evaluated. As shown in Fig. 2 , H2 spontaneously adsorbs on the Fe3C surface with an adsorption energy of -3.14 eV. The formation of CH* from adsorbed H and inherent C of the Fe3C surface requires overcoming the 1 eV energy barrier (TS-1). Thereafter the formation of CH2* and CH3* requires crossing TS-2 (0.98 eV) and TS-3 (1.03 eV), respectively, and finally, CH3* hydrogenation to CH4 still requires overcoming a higher energy barrier (1.24 eV). Due to endothermic of the hydrogenation reaction at each step, the effective energy barrier for inherent carbon hydrogenation to CH x and carbon defect formation on the surface of θ-Fe3C(031) is as high as 3.36 eV. Such a high effective energy barrier suggests that the generation of carbon defects is difficult. Therefore, the effect of carbon vacancies on CO2 adsorption activation will not be considered in the subsequent study. A schematic of the transition state structure and energy profiles for the H2 dissociation over θ-Fe3C (031) surface is shown in Fig. S1. The activation and reaction energy are 0.02 and 0.66 eV, respectively. The results show that H2 dissociation proceeds easily and that the transition state energy barriers to dissociation are so small that they can be neglected, so we did not calculate the corresponding microkinetic models. Results and discussion Adsorption activation of reactant and product molecules The adsorption of reactants and products has a great impact on the reactivity and the selectivity of carbon dioxide hydrogenation. All possible adsorption configurations for all reactants and products are investigated. Fig. 3a shows the most stable adsorption structures of CO2, H, CO, CH4, C2H4, C2H6 and H2O on θ-Fe3C(031) surface. Since CO2 adsorption is the first and most critical step of the reaction, we calculated nine different CO2 adsorption configurations with full consideration of the effect of different active sites on the adsorption structure, and determined the most stable structure by adsorption energy, as shown in Fig. S2. The 3-fold hollow site is the most robust adsorption site for carbon dioxide. The carbon atom of carbon dioxide is adsorbed in the hollow site, while the oxygen atoms are interact with the iron atom in the θ-Fe3C(031) surface. The calculated carbon dioxide adsorption energy is -0.71 eV. To further determine that the most stable adsorption configuration represents the global minimum, three lower energy CO2* (Fig. S2a, 2f and 2g) are selected for AIMD annealing simulations to validate the reasonableness of the selected most stable configuration of CO2*. As shown in Fig. 3b-d, the CO2 molecules of the three types of CO2* intermediates are basically stabilized adsorbed in the 3-fold hollow sites during the annealing process at 5 ps. This is consistent with the most stable structure selected in Fig. 3a (Fig. S2a). Moreover, compared to the 4-fold hollow site, CO2 on the 3-fold hollow site is more likely to be activated asymmetrically. This can lead to the breakdown of the π-bond of CO2, thus accelerating CO2 splitting. It is interesting to note that CO2 dissociation occurs at 4700 to 5000 fs for the CO* structure (Fig. S2g) shown in Fig. 3d, which suggests that CO2 dissociates readily after adsorption, consistent with the results in Fig. 4 . In addition, the 3-fold hollow site connected to the 4-fold hollow site is the most stabilized adsorption site of hydrogen atom. Carbon monoxide molecules tend to adsorb on the top side of iron atoms through carbon atoms with an adsorption energy of -2.08 eV. The most stable adsorption site of water is the same as carbon monoxide, which interacts with iron atoms through oxygen atoms. The adsorption energy of water is weaker than that of carbon monoxide, which is -0.65 eV. The ethylene molecules are stably adsorbed in the 4-fold hollow site, and their carbon atoms interact with the surface iron atoms with an adsorption energy of -1.42 eV. Methane and ethane are small molecules with saturated coordination, and they exist by physical adsorption on θ-Fe3C(031). After introducing dispersion correction [33–36], the energies of adsorption for methane and ethane are -0.38 eV and -0.54 eV, respectively. Due to the complex temperature variations during thermally catalyzed reactions, the inadequate consideration may lead to errors in the results of the thermocatalytic reaction. Therefore, thermal catalysis can ignore the effect of temperature on energy and describe the reaction process in terms of electronic energy [13,17]. The reaction energy barrier for carbon dioxide to break two C-O bonds on θ-Fe3C(031) is shown in Fig. 4, respectively. The transition state process for direct dissociation of CO2 is that the broken oxygen atom moves to the adjacent Fe-Fe bridge site, while remaining CO fraction migrates to the top site of the opposite Fe atom. The reaction energy barrier for CO2 to break C-O1 bond is 0.24 eV, and that of C-O2 bond is 0.43 eV, indicating that the direct cleavage of CO2 is mainly achieved through dissociation of C-O1 bond. To further insight into the dissociation of C-O, the interaction between the carbon atom and two oxygen atoms in CO2 was analyzed using the projected crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) method [37,38]. As shown in Fig. 5 a, the integrated pCOHP (IpCOHP) of C-O2 bond (-7.72 eV) is smaller than that of C-O1 (-7.45 eV), indicating that C-O2 bond is stronger than C-O1 bond, and C-O1 bond is easier to break, which is consistent with the reaction energy barrier obtained by theoretical calculation in Fig. 4. Moreover, the charge density difference between the C-O bond of the carbon dioxide adsorption configuration shows a region of negative charge between the C-O2 bond, indicating more electrons are moved from the θ-Fe3C(031) to the C-O2 bond, as shown in Fig. 4. This also confirms that stronger the C-O2 bond interaction than the C-O1 bond, which inhibiting the direct dissociation of the C-O2 bond. In addition, the strength of Fe-O bond is also an important factor affecting that of C-O bond for CO2. The projected density states of CO2 molecules adsorbed on θ-Fe3C(031) surface is shown in Fig. 6a . The sum of s and p orbitals of O2 atom is stronger than that of O1 atom, which again indicates that Fe-O2 bond is more strongly interacted than Fe-O1 bond and inhibits Fe-O2 bond dissociation. To explain the transition state of CO2 dissociation, the electronic structure is analyzed in more detail. As shown in Fig. 6b, the charge density difference of CO2 dissociation transition states over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface shows that the O part accumulates more charge than the CO part, indicating that carbon dioxide dissociation is a hetero-cleavage reaction. The reaction mechanism is that carbon dioxide achieves charge redistribution through interaction with the θ-Fe3C(031) surface, the charge of CO part is transferred to the O part, causing more charges to accumulate in the O part and destroying the C-O bond. Table 1 lists the atomic bader charges of transition states in CO2 dissociation over θ-Fe3C(031) surface, agrees with the obtained results shown in Fig. 6b. Moreover, the charge of C-O1 dissociated transition state (-1.23 δ − ) is more than that of C-O2 dissociated transition state (-1.21 δ − ), indicating that the energy barrier of C-O1 dissociated bond is reduced due to the transfer of more electrons from θ-Fe3C(031) surface. In Fig. 6c, electron localization function (ELF) map of CO2 dissociation transition states over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface shows that the electrons are highly confined to the O-C-O atoms. The ELF is 0.5 between the broken C-O bonds, indicating that there is still covalent interaction between C-O bonds. Initial activation and conversion of carbon dioxide In order to understand the initial activation and conversion process of CO2 over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface, three possible initial conversion paths were considered, including dissociation directly, hydrogenation to HCOO* as well as hydrogenation to COOH*. Fig. 7 shows the energy diagrams of the three initial transformation reaction paths, and the corresponding key structural parameters are shown in Table 2 -4. The reaction energy barrier of the CO2* dissociation directly into O* and CO* over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface is 0.24 eV, and the reaction energy (exothermic) is -1.53 eV, indicating that the CO2* direct dissociation is relatively easy in kinetics and thermodynamics, which is similar to previously reported results [32]. For the HCOO* intermediate, the C-H bond is formed by neighboring hydrogen atoms attacking the C atoms of the stably adsorbed carbon dioxide. The energy barrier for the hydrogenation of CO2* to HCOO* intermediate is 0.83 eV, and the reaction energy (endothermic) is 0.47 eV. In addition, COOH* is formed by hydrogen atoms adsorbed on the catalyst surface attacking oxygen atoms of carbon dioxide, which process with a high activation energy of 1.31 eV and reaction energy of 0.41 eV. The above results show that the initial conversion of carbon dioxide over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface is mainly through dissociation directly as well as hydrogenation to HCOO* intermediate. The forming processes of O-H bond and C-H bond are distinctly different thermodynamics and dynamics. This difference can be explained by COHP and charge density difference. The negative projection COHPs (-pCOHPs) of the C-H and O-H bond interaction strengths in the COOH* and HCOO* transition states formed by carbon dioxide hydrogenation are shown in Fig. 5b. The positive values of -pCOHP represent bonding interaction and negative values represent antibonding interaction. The -pCOHP integral below the Fermi level of the HCOO* transition state is -1.20 eV, which is smaller than the -pCOHP integral (-1.04 eV) of the COOH* transition state, which means that the formation of HCOO* transition state is more robust than that of the COOH* transition state, which is consistent with the results of reaction energy barrier. In Fig. 8 , the charge density difference shows that the charge transfer properties for O-H bond and C-H bond generated by carbon dioxide hydrogenation over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface are different. More electrons (-1.265 δ − ) were transferred from the θ-Fe3C(031) surface to the transition state of HCOO* than to the COOH* transition state (-1.065 δ − ), which suggests that the former has a stronger interaction with the catalyst than the latter. These electronic properties well explain the difference in the reaction energy barrier for the formation of O-H and C-H bonds during the hydrogenation of carbon dioxide. In addition, the trend of CO hydrogenation over θ-Fe3C(031) surface also is the similar. Previous studies have shown that the C-H bond is stronger than the O-H bond during CO2 hydrogenation, and that hydrogenation at C atoms produces a lower potential barrier than at the O atoms of CO2 or CO. Therefore, HCOO* intermediates can be formed more easily than COOH* [8,39]. Mechanism of carbon monoxide formation Carbon monoxide formation by carbon dioxide hydrogenation is a typical RWGS conversion reaction. The carbon monoxide produced can be synthesized by Fischer-Tropsch to produce value-added chemical products [25]. We have analyzed two reaction mechanisms of carbon dioxide hydrogenation to carbon monoxide on θ-Fe3C(031) surface, including CO2* direct dissociation and formation via COOH* intermediate. The crucial structure factors are listed in Table 2 and Table 3 , and the relevant reaction transition states are shown in Fig. S3 and Fig. S4. In the reaction pathway of CO2 direct dissociation, carbon monoxide is formed by carbon dioxide direct breaking of the C-O bond from CO2. During direct dissociation into CO* and O* transition states, the O1 atom moves to the adjacent Fe-Fe bridge site, and the length of the C-O1 bond is extended to 1.65 Å from 1.32 Å. The resulting O* migrates to the most stably adsorbed site and is eventually hydrogenated to form OH* and H2O*. In another carbon monoxide formation pathway with COOH* as the main intermediate, COOH* can be cleaved to CO* and OH* with 0.62 eV reaction energy barrier. However, COOH* formation needs to overcome a higher reaction energy barrier, so this reaction pathway is unfavorable compared with CO2 direct dissociation. The production of carbon monoxide competes with its further conversion. Therefore, we further studied the reaction energy (exothermic) and energy barrier for direct dissociation of CO2*, HCO* and COH* intermediates generated by carbon monoxide hydrogenation. In Fig. 9 , the energy barriers for the three reaction pathways are 1.24 eV, 1.20 eV and 1.96 eV, respectively. In addition, the CO* desorption has an energy barrier of 0.80 eV, which is lower than the energy barrier for further transformation, so the CO* intermediate tends to desorb directly after formation. Therefore, the rate control step of carbon monoxide formation over θ-Fe3C(031) surface is desorption of CO* intermediate. Mechanism of methane formation Carbon dioxide Hydrogenation over the elemental metal iron catalyst often produces a large amount of methane [40–43]. In this section, the complete reaction paths of CO2 hydrogenation to methane through CO* and HCOO* intermediates are analyzed in detail. In Table 2 and Table 4 , the key structural parameters in the reaction transition states are listed, and the relevant reaction transition states are shown in Fig. S5. In the CO2 direct dissociation path, CH4 is continuously hydrogenated through C* formed by breaking C-O bond of CO* intermediate. Huo et al. reported the formation of CH4 by CO2 hydrogenation on a variety of iron-carbon compounds, as listed in Table S1. Among them, the pathway for the generation of CH4 via hydrogenation on C atoms over Fe3C(001) is similar to our work, and their results indicate an effective potential barrier of 1.98 eV for the generation of CH4 [44]. The formation of CH4 from CO* intermediates through HCO* and COH* is thermodynamically and kinetically unfavorable. Specifically, the formation energy barriers are 1.20 and 1.96 eV for HCO* and COH*, respectively, and both of them are endothermic reactions with 0.89 and 0.98 eV reaction energies, respectively. After CO* is dissociated into C*, H* adsorbed by θ-Fe3C(031) surface continuously attacks C* to form CH*, CH2* and CH3* until CH4 is formed. CH* is also a key surface species for the formation of high carbon hydrocarbons. The reaction energy diagram of carbon dioxide forming methane through CO* intermediate is shown in Fig. 10 . In this reaction pathway, the rate control step in the CH* formation is the decomposition of CO* into atomic C*, whose reaction energy barrier is 1.24 eV. The effective barrier is decided from the gradually C* hydrogenation to form CH3*, which is 2.99 eV. Similar to previously reported results (2.29 eV) [31]. Another reaction pathway that forms CH4 is the conversion of carbon dioxide through HCOO* intermediates to CHx* species, and then continuous hydrogenation to produce methane, which is shown in the corresponding energy profile in Fig. 11 . The intermediate adsorption structure as well as the transition state lattice structure are shown in the Supplementary material Fig. SI. The reaction energy barrier for the hydrogenation of carbon dioxide to HCOO* is intermediate, which is 0.83 eV, as shown in Fig. 7. Therefore, different conversion modes of HCOO* are further studied, that is, HCOO* was directly dissociated into HCO* and O*, and hydrogenated into intermediates of HCOOH* as well as H2COO*. HCOO* hydrogenation to HCOOH* and H2COO* have a high reaction energy barrier and high reaction energy. In detail, HCOO* hydrogenation to HCOOH* requires to overcoming a reactive energy barrier of 2.05 eV and an endotherm of 1.47 eV, as shown in Fig. S6. The HCOO* hydrogenation to H2COO* requires overcoming a slightly lower reaction energy barrier (1.88 eV) compared to HCOOH*. Therefore, we subsequently do not consider the HCOO to HCOOH micromovement model. And the endothermic of this reaction is 0.55 eV. The HCOO* direct dissociation to HCO* and O* is thermodynamically favorable with an exothermic energy of -1.11 eV, and a reaction energy barrier of 0.76 eV, which is very low compared to the other two reaction energy barriers. The HCO* produced by the reaction tends to be directly dissociated to form CH*, rather than hydrogenated to form H2CO*. The energy barrier of HCO* direct dissociation is 0.69 eV and exothermic 1.48 eV. The CH* continues to hydrogenate to form methane. In this reaction pathway, the rate control step in the forming of CH* monomer is the carbon dioxide oxygenation to generate HCOO*, while the active energy barrier of methane formation is 2.47 eV. By comparing the two reaction pathways, the results show that the methane production effective energy barrier is lower than that of the direct dissociation of CO2 in the reaction pathway with HCOO* as the main intermediate. Therefore, the dominant reaction pathway of carbon dioxide hydrogenation to methane over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface is CO2* → HCOO* → HCO* → CH* → CH2* → CH3* → CH4*. Mechanism of C2 hydrocarbon generation In the traditional Fischer-Tropsch synthesis reaction, CH* and CH2* are the key intermediates for the synthesis of high carbon hydrocarbons [45,46]. The results in Section 3.4 show that CH* is the most critical monomer of C1 species over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface. This section further studies all possible elementary reactions for the synthesis of C2 hydrocarbons. Table 4 lists the elemental reaction energy barrier and reaction heat involving the forming of C2 hydrocarbons over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface. The corresponding intermediate adsorption structure is shown in the Supplementary material Fig. S5. There are two possibilities for the initial C-C bond formation over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface, which are CH* + CH* and CH2* + CH2 *, the latter of which has a slightly lower energy barrier. Yet, because of the high energy barrier and reaction energy (exothermic) of CH* hydrogenation to CH2*, the two will compete with each other under actual reaction conditions. In addition, the high coupling energy barrier of CH2* and CH3* is not conducive to the occurrence on the catalyst surface. Therefore, the Table 4 indicates that the ethylene formation and its further hydrogenation to ethane over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface are endothermic reactions, and the effective energy barrier is significantly higher than that of methane. Microkinetic modeling The selectivity of the reaction products cannot be determined by the reaction energy barrier alone, and the detailed reaction rate needs to be analyzed in combination with the microkinetic model [47,48]. Therefore, the steady state approximations and mean field were used to construct a microkinetic modeling to analyze the relativity selectivity of critical products. The key parameters applied for the microkinetic modeling, the activation barriers, the reaction energies, the forward and reverse pre-exponential factors of the primitive reactions, are listed in Table 5 . The corresponding temperature in the model is set to 623 K, which is same as the experimental conditions [12]. The total pressure is set to 40 bar, and the partial pressures of CO2, H2 and other small molecules are set to 10 bar, 30 bar, and 0.001 bar, respectively. The coverage distribution of the key species such as H*, O*, OH* and C* over θ-Fe3C(031) surface at different temperatures is shown in Fig. 12a . The surface coverage (ML, mono layer) of each species determines the reaction rate of each primitive, and thus affects the relative selectivity of the products. The theoretical results show that the active sites over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface are mainly occupied by these species. It can be seen in Fig. 12a that the surface coverage of H* decreases as the temperature increases, that of O* and OH* remains basically unchanged, and that of C* increases with increasing temperature. H* occupies the largest surface coverage, indicating that the catalyst has a good hydrogenation capacity. In order to investigate the relative selectivity of carbon dioxide hydrogenation products over θ-Fe3C(031) surface, the TOF of the main product of carbon dioxide hydrogenation at different temperatures was calculated. As the temperature increases, the TOF of each product increases, as shown in Fig. 12b. Among them, carbon monoxide is the most selective. The microkinetic simulation results show that the surface coverage of CO is up to 95 %. Due to the coverage effect, the adsorption energy of CO decreases with the increase of CO coverage, as shown in Fig. S7. This is the main reason for the higher production rate of CO. The effect of surface O atoms on CO adsorption is not considered in this process. Because the reaction energy barrier for O* hydrogenation (1.63 eV) is smaller than that for CO desorption (2.08 eV), it indicates that the O* hydrogenation reaction occurs preferentially, resulting in a lower O* coverage, and therefore has little effect on CO adsorption. The selectivity of ethylene and methane is basically similar. In detail, the ethylene selectivity is higher than that of methane at low temperature, while the selectivity of methane gradually increases with increasing temperature, and even exceeds that of ethylene. Ethane has the lowest selectivity. Combined with the conclusion in Section 3.2, the direct carbon dioxide dissociation over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface has a lower energy barrier, indicating that the major product of CO2 hydrogenation is CO. Therefore, θ-Fe3C(031) surface is a good catalyst for reverse water gas conversion. Conclusions We systematically studied the reaction pathways of CO2 hydrogenation to methane, ethylene, ethane, and carbon monoxide over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface by first-principles calculations and microkinetic modeling. Combined with DOS, charge density difference and ELF electron structure analysis, it is proved that CO2* prefers to directly dissociate and form CO* intermediates over the θ-Fe3C(031). Because of the high energy barrier of the next step of CO* hydrogenation conversion, it tends to desorb to form carbon monoxide rather than further conversion to hydrocarbons. The complete reaction pathway calculation shows that after CHx* formation from HCOO* by CO2, the effective energy barrier for the intermediate desorption of CO* to CO is lowest compared to carbon-carbon coupling to ethylene and ethane as well as further hydrogenation to methane. Therefore, the major product of CO2 hydrogenation is CO over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface rather than hydrocarbons. A complete reaction network is constructed by combining the microkinetic modeling. It is found that the coverage of H* species on the θ-Fe3C(031) is higher compared to other species, which could effectively inhibit the further oxidation of the catalyst. Therefore, the catalyst has good stability under reaction conditions. In addition, the results of microkinetic modeling show that CO has the highest relative selectivity, which also confirms the trend of reaction energy barrier. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic conversion of carbon dioxide into high-value compounds is a promising strategy for reducing carbon dioxide emissions. In the reduction of CO2 to hydrocarbons, the active point and reaction mechanism of iron-based catalysts are still unclear. Here, we systematically investigated the complete reaction path of carbon dioxide hydrogenation to methane, ethylene, ethane, and carbon monoxide over the θ-Fe3C(031) surface using first principles calculations. The electronic structure analysis shows that carbon dioxide tends to dissociate directly on the θ-Fe3C(031) surface to form CO* instead of COOH* and HCOO* intermediates. Due to the high energy barrier for CO* hydrogenation, it tends to desorb forming CO product instead of further transformation into hydrocarbons. In addition, the microkinetic model proved that the H* species coverage on the θ-Fe3C(031) crystal surface is highly, which could effectively inhibit the further oxidation of the catalyst, indicating the catalyst to be highly stable. Meanwhile, carbon monoxide behaved the highest relative selectivity. These results reveal the key intermediates and reaction paths of carbon dioxide hydrogenation over θ-Fe3C(031) catalyst surface and further illustrate the key factors affecting its product selectivity, providing a theoretical basis and guidance for the design and synthesis of the catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation over θ-Fe3C catalyst: First-principles calculations combined with micro-kinetic modeling
